definition: To make (something) better; to increase the value or productivity (of something).
The process of imparting knowledge, skill and judgment.
A long-standing group of people sharing cultural aspects such as language, dress, norms of behavior and artistic forms.
Diligent inquiry or examination to seek or revise facts, principles, theories, applications, etc.; laborious or continued search after truth.
A festive gathering to foster introductions.
A set of structured activities.
The state of being free from physical or psychological disease, illness, or malfunction; wellness.
A medical examination.
Any solid substance that can be consumed by living organisms, especially by eating, in order to sustain life.
Grief, sorrow.
A substance which specifically promotes healing when ingested or consumed in some way.
The art or science of cultivating the ground, including the harvesting of crops, and the rearing and management of livestock
The condition or feeling of being safe; security; certainty.
Pertaining to the environment.
A logical clause or phrase that a conditional statement uses. The phrase can either be true or false.
An abnormal condition of a human, animal or plant that causes discomfort or dysfunction; distinct from injury insofar as the latter is usually instantaneously acquired.
An advantage; help or aid from something.
A means of indemnity against a future occurrence of an uncertain event.
Of or relating to the mind or an intellectual process.
An instance of a disease or poor health.
Health, safety, happiness and prosperity; well-being in any respect.
Any activity designed to develop or hone a skill or ability.

A physician; a member of the medical profession; one who is trained and licensed to heal the sick or injured. The final examination and qualification may award a doctor degree in which case the post-nominal letters are D.O., DPM, M.D., DMD, DDS, in the US or MBBS in the UK.
A large medical facility, usually in a building with multiple floors, where seriously ill or injured patients are given extensive medical and/or surgical treatment.
A style of living that reflects the attitudes and values of a person or group.
(Cause of) discomfort.
A person or animal who receives treatment from a doctor or other medically educated person.
Enjoying health and vigor of body, mind, or spirit: well.
The prevention, treatment, and management of illness or the preservation of mental and physical well-being through the services offered by the medical, nursing, and allied health professions.
The food and beverage a person or animal consumes.
Help; assistance; succor, relief.
The prevention, treatment, and management of illness or the preservation of mental and physical well-being through the services offered by the medical, nursing, and allied health professions.
To breastfeed: to feed (a baby) at the breast; to suckle.
The condition of being fit, suitable or appropriate.
The science and practice of community hygiene; includes preventive medicine, health education, sanitation and environmental safety.
The organic process by which an organism assimilates food and uses it for growth and maintenance.
One's emotional well-being, especially with reference to one's outlook on life, ability to cope with stress or the absence of a mental disorder.
A reproductive organism (especially such as in an insect).
The hygienic disposal or recycling of waste.
The science of health, its promotion and preservation.
A state of health, happiness and/or prosperity.
The branch of science dealing with the spread and control of diseases, viruses, concepts etc. throughout populations or systems.
Of, pertaining to, or providing nutrition.
The quality or state of being in good health.
The state of being obese due to an excess of body fat.
An unaccented beat at the start of a musical phrase.
A thing that prevents, hinders, or acts as an obstacle to.
A psychiatric diagnosis denoting a persistent, often chronic, mental illness characterised by abnormal perception, thinking, behavior and emotion, often marked by delusions.
All the physical things constructed by humans as aids to living.
A state of health, happiness and/or prosperity.
The act, practice, or occupation of supervising and taking care of young children.
A therapist who treats physical injury or dysfunction, usually with exercise.
A thing that prevents, hinders, or acts as an obstacle to.
The process by which an individual is safely exposed in a controlled manner to a material that is designed to prime their immune system against that material.
A routine visit to the doctor, dentist, or the like.
Having pronounced muscle development through weightlifting, bodybuilding, or other physical exercise.

The state of organisms preceding their death, characterized by biological processes such as metabolism and reproduction and distinguishing them from inanimate objects; the state of being alive and living.
Injury or harm; the condition or measure of something not being intact.
A protective layer over a body, vehicle, or other object intended to deflect or diffuse damaging forces.
The energy and strength for continuing to do something over a long period of time; power of sustained exertion, or resistance to hardship, illness etc.
The process where the cells in the body regenerate and repair themselves.
The whole duration of a being, whether animal, plant, or other kind, being alive.
Physical frame.
A state that is characterized by compulsive drug use or compulsive engagement in rewarding behavior, despite negative consequences.
(physical) Matter, material.
The quality of being (especially visually) attractive, pleasing, fine or good-looking; comeliness.
Anything that protects or defends; defense; shelter; protection.
In good health.
State of being disabled; deprivation or want of ability; absence of competent physical, intellectual, or moral power, means, fitness, and the like.
The emotion of being happy; joy.
The quality or degree of being strong.
A muscular organ that pumps blood through the body, traditionally thought to be the seat of emotion.
The act of traveling; passage from place to place.
State of being disabled; deprivation or want of ability; absence of competent physical, intellectual, or moral power, means, fitness, and the like.
The act or process of regaining or repossession of something lost.
Of or pertaining to psychology.
The formation and excretion of sweat; perspiration.
The impetus behind all motion and all activity.
